Posted: May 31, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Retro Review: Max Payne 

			Views: 73		

			http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Max_Payne - widescreen fix http://store.steampowered.com/app/12140/ Follow me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/Little_B_Gaming		

Max Payne. Maximum pain. His name hides his destiny, never to find peace, to lose everyone he cares about, constantly to be in pain and always be on the edge of life and death. This is the tragic story of the title character of the revolutionary Max Payne.In one faithful night, everything he loves is gone in a blink of an eye and the world around him crumble. Arriving home he find his baby daughter and wife killed by junkies, under the influence of a new found drug on the streets of NY, called Valkyre or just V. After the funeral Max transfer to DEA and goes undercover, determine to find where the drug comes from. Only two agents, Alex and B.B. knows who he is. Three years later, Max finally have break on the Valkyre case. He recieve a messege from B.B. to meet Alex. Max have a bad feeling about this and he wasn't wrong. Alex get killed and he takes the blame for the murder. With nothing left to lose, Max takes the path of vengeance. He is been chased by everyone – police, mobsters, freaks and so on. This wild chase is happening in the middle of huge winter storm, as if it comes end of the world. From here follows twist and turns, betrayls, meeting with insane villians, bad guys helping you with information, corruptions, blackmail and so on. The story is one of the best things here. It's written by Sam Lake, who is the face of Max. The script is full of metaphors and references to scandinavian mythology. It's brilliantly written.Cutscene are great and original. They are looking like graphic novel with neo-noir vibe and the voice of James McCaffrey make them even more memorable. Because of the moderate budget, Sam Lake is the face of the main characters and friends and colleagues are other people in the game. The cutscenes are filled with the inner monologs of Max, from which we find out the story and his mental state.Even so many years later all this is still kind of impressive. But what is most memorable and revolutionary is in the gameplay section. The thing i'm talking about is bullet-time. It gives you more time to react and make more accurate shots. You can see to the silhouette of Max an hourglass. There is shown how much bullet-time you have. With a press of a button everything slows down and you can even see where the bullets fly. If you dive in it takes little part of it, so you have to decide how to use it. The hourglass drains quickly and the only way to fiil it is to kill enemies without using bullet-time. You have to use it wisely, because slowing down time is essential for reaching the end. The game is highly inspired by Hong Kong action movie, especially those of John Woo.The game is old school and doesn't have regenerating health. You restore it by the most logical thing for the game – painkillers. You find them in spread around the levels. Sometimes they are not in obvious places.The feeling of using bullet-time and blast through small group of bad guys is awesome.You are almost invulnerable. But you are not. Max life is fragile and even on the lowest difficulty, you can die in a blink of an eye. The game is hard, but fair. She will  kick your♥♥♥♥♥right from the start and ask do you want more. Most of the times when you die, it's player fault. Some enemies are cheaply placed and you don't have enough time to react. So quick save is alway an option. I don't want to know how is in the higher difficulties.Max have substantial, but fairly standard arsenal of weapons – pistols, shotgun, double barrel shotgun, assault rifle, uzi, granade launcher, granades, sniper, Molotov and my favorite – Jackhammer. In close range is irreplaceable. The only weapon i don't like is the shotgun. The reloading speed is slow and i often die, when i use it. Here you can find one interesting and innovative thing. When you shoot with the sniper, the camera follows the bullet. Sound familiar? Few years later this will be the main feature in Sniper Elite.The level design is awesome. They fairly diverse – abandone buildings, harbor, mansion and so on. Some places are even turn in to a brothel. There you can see, especially in the abandon buildings, the darkside of NY. The atmosphere is dark, grimm and depressing, particularly when you see the consequences on people using Valkyre. Death is above them and waiting to collect their souls. There are other more bright places like mansion, skyscraper and so on. But there heavily armed men are waiting for you. There are two different level. Little anoying to navigate, but they are not long. They are dreams, representing the mental state of Max, his fears, desires and the guilt he feels all the time. Dark and confused like himself.The graphics are bad, but it's 14 year old game. This is the biggest problem here. Human models are not pretty to look at and not different enough. When you take in account release date, modest budget of 3 milion dollars for four years and the small Remedy team, it's not suprising. But in the end the game sold 7,5 million copies.14 years later the sound design is still impressive. Guns doesn't sound bombastic, they are not too loud. When using pistol, you hear pistol.The voice acting is fantastic. Even people with small roles are doing great job, but most memorable is of James McCafferey. There is an actior voicing one of the bosses, lunatic using V, can make you shiver, when you hear him talking.You will remmember the music in Max Payne, especially the singnature music theme. Deep beat, followed by piano and little bit later guitar and drums can be heard. All this sets the mood for the sad and dark story of Max. The others are also good. Energetic tracks with pinch of tension in the style of 80's action movies. Some places don't have music playing and this just adds to the atmosphere. Phenomenal soundtrack. When you consider the budget of Remedy, all of this is incredible. Modern games should take a notes.This game is classic and everyone have to play. It even run great on Windows 7. You have the feeling you are in John Woo movie, where hero pour a rain of bullets and skillfully avoid them. Despite that the graphics didn't age  well, every person have to see the roots of this series and the beginning of bullet-time. It doesn't matter how other games call it. The foundation is laid here. The story and gameplay are still great. Fantastic soundtrack, great and inovative gameplay, original and interesting cutscene, superb action. Here is also laid the foundation of one of the most beloved games from me – Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne. I highly recommend it.

												This game has aged incredibly well. INSANELY well. It's a blast to play, the graphics are rarely an issue, and good storytelling doesn't get worse over time. Max Payne's signature jump...things are always satisfying, and slaughtering the infinite hordes of sleazy New Yorkers is as satisfying as any modern TPS, with a dark, comic book story to boot. Note, this game is DARK. Like, really, really dark. As far as I could see, there wasn't a single human (apart from Max's wife, who is dead) who wasn't either severely psyschologically disturbed, depressed, psychotic, self-centered, or just an all-around slimeball. There are no happy endings, and Max knows it.

												max payne (1) is one of those games that you won't really get the appeal unless you play it, and in many ways you could claim it's a niche game... it juxtaposes the 'mindless shooter' gameplay elements with a very deeply developed story that could easily be ignored if you just want to shoot things and jump around. however, if you let yourself get sucked into the story, it borders on a psychological horror mixed with a few cliche 'good guy turned anti-hero searching for total revenge' story elements. the best part is, although it's a very serious and dark game, the game does not one bit take itself seriously. there is enough tongue-in-cheek humor to last a lifetime, and at times, the game will even mock itself. max payne is definitely one of the best action shooters ever made, even though it's a bit dated nowadays. i would recommend it if you're looking for an older style of gameplay with a few tweaks and perks that can't be found in most, or if you want a high-octane game with a deep, gritty storyline. it's definitely a game i am glad i decidd to give a chance years ago despite it not being one i'd usually care to try. also if you like it, max payne 2 is everything awesome about the first game made tenfold. this game will always hold a large part of my heart.EDIT:steam holiday sale has both 1 and 2 for 2.99 and if you have any doubts about this game you have no excuse (unless you're broke) not to try it now. get this game, it's amazing.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												So this was a very fun game. The idea is that it is game based on noir detective type movies/comics and it does it beautifully. The cutscenes are presented as graphic novels that look very dark and grimey as they should be and the voice over work sets the tone perfectly. The gameplay sections has a realistic, albeit very outdated, look to it. Some really nice touches are that the blood, spent ammo, dead bodies and such never disappear to give it less of a "video game" like feel. Another good thing about the game is bullet-time. It makes the game slow down so that you can have more time to think out what you are doing while in a chaotic gun fight. You can also do slo-mo dives which lets you shoot enemies while (hopefully) not getting hit yourself. Another thing about this game is that it is very difficult. You die at the drop of a hat on the easiest and this was probably done so that Payne seems more like just a regular guy with a lot of luck as opposed to being super human. Sure he racks up a huge kill count by the end but it is very easy to die to even just one enemy.All in all very good game. I give it 5 constipated looking faces out of 5.

Posted: October 7, 2016
												Max Payne is one of those great games that needed to be made. Either so Remedy could go on to make Alan Wake, or quantum break or just because the genre is lacking in quality. It's aged well, and at the same time been left behind by the constantly evolveing and ever tweaked control schemes of shooters whether third person or otherwise. Worth playing but for best experience you'll want to use keyboard and mouse. I recommend playing this before any other remedy titles not because you need to but because you should. just like playing omikron: The Nomad Soul before Indigo Prophecy, it gives you the oportunity to appreciate how far the developer come. When you've moved on to their more recent titles you'll be even more impressed than you would have without haveing played max payne, and in tern be more curious about future projects. I think its always better to be familiar with the developer because in some copacity you will know what your paying for or at least know what to expect with future IP's.for the time it came out I'd give it a 10/10 graphically on par with GTA 3 if not slightly more polished

Posted: May 23, 2015
												Max Payne was released in 2001. Even after so many years it still remain one of my favorite games ever. It's just perfect. So why did I fall in love with Max Payne?- Shooting.Those weapons are really made well. If you are using shotgun it feels like shotgun, it can send bad guys flying for few meters, but you also can fly pretty high too. Throught whole game you use all of the weapons in game. Shooting in Max Payne is pure fun.- Slow motion.Probably the best slowmo in history of gaming. I mean it. Even Matrix games never had slowmo this amazing. Jumping from the corner to surprise your enemies, jumping throught the doors to surprise your enemies, and slowly falling on the ground, but faster their dead bodies.- Story and characters.There are great and memorable characters in this game. The story in form of comic is interesting as the story itself."Clear as vodka.""No Payne, No Gain."And of course full of specific humour. Narration is perfect too.- Music.Just at the very beggining you have hard time starting game. Why? Max Payne have this amazing theme music. It makes you wait for the whole thing, it's playing, and playing, and you can't stop listening to it. When I heard it first time I had chills. It's perfect, it describes perfect, without use of any words, what kind of game Max Payne is. You will want to hear more of it as you progress with the story.- Difficult level.Max Payne isn't a easy game. Even while playing on lowest difficult level the bad guys can pack whole shotgun shell in your head, or something on your back, and kill you without any problem. Same with them throwing grenades or molotov cocktails. Once they will get better stuff than pistols you will need something more than just slowmo to get rid of them. It's easy to get hurt and there aren't enough painkillers to get rid of all this Payne...To be honest, I could praise this game all the time. Don't mind that it's an old game. It aged very well, graphics still looks great (at least for me) and it's full of things that you won't find in gaming nowadays. Even people playing Max Payne for the first time, so many years after release, are surprised how they could miss something like that. If you haven't played it, you must do it. You won't regret it.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Probably one of my favorite games ever.  Max Payne bleeds noir and is oozing with style, like a cross between a John Woo and Quentin Tarantino movie.  The story is pretty standard ho hum stuff, but the way it is delivered is phenomenal.  The comic strip cutscenes are particularly nice since they still look good more than a decade after the game has become graphically outdated.  Payne's narration is great stuff; describing the world and ongoings around him with a surrealistic, morose style in typical noir fashion.There are a few problems though.  For one, if you have Windows 7 or beyond you'll have trouble getting the game to run.  You'll need a community made sound patch for the cutscenes and you'll need to be sure to run this game in compatibility mode, otherwise it won't work.Technical issues aside, Max Payne is a really hard game, but that difficulty is often unfair and it can be a source of frequent frustration.  The enemies don't have realistic reactions and will literally snap towards you the milisecond you appear in their general vicinity, shooting at you with pin point accuracy to the point where a guy with a sawed off shotgun will snipe you from across the room.You'll find a lot of guns becoming useless for you while the enemy still often uses them to great effect, which is a real bummer.  The signature dual berretas become really useless really really fast, and the shotgun becomes equally useless later on since you cannot blow anyone off their feet not even in melee range, and they'll gun you down while you get a second shot in since they barely recoil to a shotgun blast to the face.Familiarize yourself with quick save/quick load and try to strategize your approach to difficult encounters with bullet time, but really, Max Payne puts it best; "It wasn't about how smart or how good you were. It was chaos and luck, and anyone who thought different was a fool."Also, the nightmare scenes are cool, but the platforming is... well, a nightmare.Anyway, none of that is enough to deter me from loving this game and that in itself should be a glowing testament to the quality of its other areas.  The sequel is just as good too, if not even better.  But start here.

												'They were all dead. The final gunshot was an exclamation mark on everything that had led to this point. I released my finger from the trigger, and it was over.' If there's one video game opening that has never left me, it's Max Payne. The grim, almost relieved voice speaking out over New York City from a top the Aesir Tower gripped me from the start. Max Payne is part video game, part comic and a proud piece of video gaming history. The best thing about Max Payne, other than the protagonist's name obviously, is bullet time. Slow down time to show off your moves and make every shot count.  Probably the only flaw of Max Payne was that it has to end. The average player should be able to clear the game within 7 hours quite easily on the first play through. Harder difficulties and a time trial mode are unlocked following the first play through and will test your abilities. 11/10 would noir again.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Horrible film and infamously bad player model aside, one of the best pre-Resident Evil 4 third person shooters. 8/10+Who knew that John Woo and film noir mixed so perfectly?+Surprisingly well written story+Great vocal performance by James Mccafrey+Those dream sequences!+Plenty of classic noir references, and some odd nods to Norse and Greek mythology+The gameplay isn't quite like any other third person shooter, it has a fast paced, run and gun style; almost like a third person Quake or Unreal+The Slo-Mo, while kind of a gimmick, is still fun to use.+The final level is glorious. It is the very definition of a climax.+/- It is fiendishly difficult, there are some sequences that completely rely on trial and error. You will have to mash that quicksave button.-The villain isn't really fleshed out that well (she is only introduced around an hour in)-I would have liked to have seen more of Vladmeer and Mona.-I mentioned the quicksave, well that is because there is not really any type of autosaving, or checkpoints. If you die, and forget to save frequently, you have to restart the entire level.-The secondary voice actors are pretty meh. The repeated sound clips of enemies yelling "IT'S PAYNE!" or "PAYNE?!" get annoying quickly-(now for nitpicks) Max's infamous in game face. The game's writer, Sam Lake, is quite talented... As a writer, not a model. He did not need to devote his likeness for the player model. It looks kind of... rough.-Those .5 seconds when you can't shoot after diving.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Max Payne is a game without a lot of the "advancements" made in the 3rd person shooter genre. The game features open yet often small levels, with very little cover or areas to hide behind. The game will often kill you suddenly and without warning, with enemies showing up out of nowhere and many blind entrances through doors walking you right into death with enemies already pointing guns at the door. And there is little to no checkpointing, with the player having to make their own with quicksaves, which they'll definitely need because as I mentioned the game will kill you suddenly and without mercy regularly.The gameplay consists of utilizing the bullet time and dodge mechanics to outmanuver bullets, shoot more precisely and deal more damage in a short period of time to kill enemies before they kill you. The game has no cover mechanics and attempting to pick off enemies from behind cover rarely works. If you stand still in a fight, you will likely die. You must abuse horizontal movement and bullet time to your advantage to keep the enemy from getting a bead on you, because shots are often lethal.During my first playthrough, I was frequently frustrated by the game. When I reconsidered the trial and error battles as puzzles I enjoyed myself much more. Every abrupt and sudden death which was previously unfair suddenly became elaborate puzzles I had to solve using bullet time and focus firing priority targets. By the time I reached the end of the game I realized some techniques relating to the bullet time mechanic I could use to play more efficiently and immediately played it again on the next difficulty. The second playthrough was even more fun as things were more challenging but I felt like I had only just grasped the bullet time mechanics and was making full use of it at last. When I had finished the second run I was contemplating what I could do to play better for the next difficulty. Very few games new or old compel me to do that, and it was that hard "unfairness" that made me want to come back.The game's plot is enjoyably campy. It's the kind of sincere corniness that games had before they tried too hard at being quirky and random. It's enjoyable and skippable which makes it easier to replay the game without playing through interactive cutscenes.Buy Max Payne if you like arcade-like 3rd person action games and trial and error difficulty.

Very few games new or old compel me to do that, and it was that hard "unfairness" that made me want to come back.The game's plot is enjoyably campy. It's the kind of sincere corniness that games had before they tried too hard at being quirky and random. It's enjoyable and skippable which makes it easier to replay the game without playing through interactive cutscenes.Buy Max Payne if you like arcade-like 3rd person action games and trial and error difficulty.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												This review is for the game ''Max Payne'',a third-person shooter video game,developed by the video game company Remedy Entertainment.The game was published by Gathering of Developers(now known as Gathering,a daughter company of Take-Two Interactive) in North Americaand 3D Realms in Europe on July 2001 for Microsoft Windows.and released in Semptember 22 on 2006(in Europe).The game can be run through Microsoft Windows,Playstation 2,Xbox,Game Boy Advance,Mac OS,iOS & Android.The game uses the MAX-FX 1.0.Genre(s):Third-person shooterMode(s):Single-playerDistribution:CD-ROM,DVD,cartridge,digital download.PlotThe game takes place in New York city,in December 2001,where you take control of a former NYPD officer and a renegade DEA (Drug Enforcement Administration),Max Payne,who's being arrested by the police at the top of a skyscraper.While he is being arrested he experiences a flashback which explains his life story and why he is being chased.On August 22. 1998 NYPD detective,Max payne,just finishing his work goes home only to find his wife and his newborn daughter,Rose,brutally murdered.Max kills the junkies responsible for the murder of his loved ones but he is too late.After that incident he transfers to DEA in order to find out who is responsible and ultimately take revenge.The game's content majority takes place during the last two days while Max is operating inside the Punchinello Mafia family,under the Don Angelo Punchinello(family's head),responsible for the trafficking of the Valkyr drug.After given a message to meet Alex(his Dea contact and Max's best friend) Max find Alex on the NYC Rosco Subway Station.His arrival at the Station results in encountering Jack's Lupino mobster group(Punchinello's crime family underboss)who were attempting an armed robbery.There he will come in contact with Aesir Corporation(just company bonds),a mysterious New York corporation,who is bound to play an important role on the story later on.Later on Max Payne will come in contact with Alex who informs him that Max has been exposed by a mole in the Punchinello family.Seconds later Alex gets killed by a possible Killer Suit(Aesir's corporation hitmen).To make things worse Payne becomes suspect because of the fact that he is still an undercover,therefore an enemy,and is now chased by both the Punchinello crime family and also by the Deputy Chief Jim Bravura.Succeding the Station's events he goes to a Lupino's motel where he finds and kills the Finito Brothers(Vinnie's Gognitti subordinate).After that Max travels in one of Lupino's bars,finds the diary of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥,Candy,and the fact that he sends video tapes of her and a mysterious <<one-eyed Alfred>>(an important figure later on).Eventually Max finds and kills Rico Muerte(a former hitman working for Punchinello) and Candy.In the bar Max found the location of Gognitti.After chasing Gognitti from his apartment through the city and the subway,Max learns about a nightclub named Ragna Rok.There Max spares Gognitti and Max proceeds in killing the so called ''antichrist'' Lupino.After killing him and his men he encounters Mona Sax,Lisa's Punchinello twin sister and contract killer,who sedates Max by throwing something in his drink,telling him that she wants to kill the Don too.After a dream about his family's death he wakes up and manages to escape the Mafia base and after that he finds himself in the bar where he earlier killed Rico Muerte.There Max finds Frank "The Bat" Niagara who had captured Max and was going to kill him.After these events Max is approached by Vladimir Lem(Russian's mafia leader and Punichinello's prime enemy) and is proposed a brief alliance.With Vlad's help Max seizes the cargo ship Charon and kills Boris Dime,a Punchinello subordinate(former Lem's subordinate),and arranges a meeting in Don's restaurant,only to bee a set up resulting in the bombing of the place and the killing of the rest of Punchinello's men(by Max Payne of course).Max Payne,then,heads for Punchinello's residence only to find and kill the Trio(Vince Mugnaio,Pilate Providence (AKA "Big Brother"),and Joe "Deadpan" Salem) Don's most feared hitman group.Max later finds the corpse of the Don's wife(Mona's twin sister) and discovers that the Don is just a pawn for the Aesir Corporation.The Don is killed by the agents of Nicole Horne,the Ceo,and Payne is being injected an overose of the Valkyr drug.Payne then suffers nightmares about his family but manages to survive the dosage.The game now takes it's final course.Max finds out and underground military research complex where inside that complex Valkyr is being researched,an experiment that attempted to improve but failed to do so the stamina and morale of the U.S soldiers.The drug research was halted but Horne ,who was the leading expert of the so called Valhalla Project,after becoming the Ceo she restarted the research and used the company as a front for producing the Valkyr.Max escapes the complex after a successful destruction by the Aesir Corporation in order to destroy the evidence.Later on Max encounters B.B who admits that was bribed by Nicole Horne to kill Max and Alex.Max then chases the traitor B.B Hensley(Payne's other DEA contact) and kills him.After doing so Max gets a phone call from Alfred Wooden(''one-eyed Alfred''),asking him to come to Asgard Building.There he learns that Alfred is a part of the Inner Circle,a powerful society with strong ties to the U.S government.The Inner Circle want to stop Nicole Horne but they can't because ofthe fact that Alfred was being blackmailed by the Punchinello family over the tapes coming from the Lupino's pimp club.They ask Max to kill Horne in exchange for dropping the charges against him.Suddenly,Aesir assassins invade the building and kill everyone except Max,who manages to run away,and Woden,who pretends to have died.In the end Max arrives at the Aesir Corporation building,kills the guards and at the top of the building confronts Nicole Horne who boards a helicopter.Max shoots wires that holds the buildin's antenna,which breaks off and crashes onto the helicopter,successfully killing Horne.While these events Mona Sax dies from a shot in the head but her body vanishes unknowningly.In the end Max,as said in Plot's section first paragraph,gets arrested by the policemen.Max has finally taken his revenge for the death of his loved ones.Max smiles satisfied while knowing that Woden will get the charges dropped and Woden smiles as well,satisfied that Horne has been stopped.Gameplay-ThemesMax Payne is a third-person shooter with neo-noir elements.You can use many weapons(9mm pistol,jackhammer,ingram,sniper rifle etc.).Unfortunatelly you can't use any means of transportation in the entire game.There's a useful thing you can do called Bullet-Time that you can use in order to slow time and dodge or fire at your enemy.As for the themes the game's elements are named from figures and mythsfrom Norse mythology(Valkyr,Valhalla,Ragnarok,Woden which means Odin,Aesir,Asgard,Balder etc.).RecapI find this game an absolute work of art.The story,the missions,the objectives,the plot,the gameplay everything to be absolutely breath-taking and mind blowing.It has a little audio problems but can be solved in a matter of minutes.I definitely recommend this game.Don't be fooled by the fact that it's a 2001 game.Can easily compete in fun with modern 2013-14 games in my opinion.Thank you Remedy Entertainment and Rockstar Games for this wonderful game.P.S Max Payne has only started his journey through the night.The pain has only just begun.More will follow.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Max Payne is a little bit like buying a fifty-year-old escort: it hasn't aged well, it's not pretty, and it takes a little bit of convincing to get everything running, but it gets the job done. The performance is not stellar, but hey, maybe you got it on a discount, maybe you know a guy. This is why I don't recommend the game.With that aside, it's pretty great. The noir is noir, the story is acceptable, the metaphors are a tired rain on a dreary autumn afternoon, never sure quite when to give up for snow. They do seem a touch forced, but there's a charm in that, along with the graphic novel-style storytelling. The gameplay is frankly, at this point, weak and stale, and enemy accuracy is wildly unpredictable, which is no fun when every bullet hurts and you're quickloading/quicksaving all the time to avoid getting scraped in a scuffle. As frustrating and tiresome as that got, I still found myself playing on to hear Max mutter exposition in his slightly congested voice. I did beat it, but I won't play the unlocked difficulty levels. Finishing was enough for me.TL;DR: I don't recommend it, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. Prepare yourself by grabbing the sound and widescreen fixes.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												If you're going to read this, then focus. Put a couple of minutes aside. Pay full attention to me, because this isn't just a review. I'm going to pour my heart into this because I feel that's what this game deserves. This isn't just something you can score. At first, this game's story is exactly like your standard anime, but it very quickly becomes something far greater. In my 32 hour campaign, there wasn't a single second in which I wasn't enjoying the absolute hell out of everything the game had to offer me. The adorable characters, the amazing story, the graphics of all of the spells...there wasn't a single second where I wasn't entertained. It got to the point where once I reached the end of the game, I wasn't crying just because of the way the story ended, but also because of the very fact that the game is over now. Sure I knew I could do a new game plus, but something about finishing the game was just so heart wrenching. I can't even remember the last time I shed a tear, and I am a rather stoic man, so it symbolizes a lot that this amazingly emotional game managed to make me cry in different ways at the same time.Somehow, the repetitive combat isn't a bad thing. The spell effects of each and every spell are entertaining and beautiful enough to keep you interested in seeing them forever. Getting experience and skill points is fun no matter what, to the point where even the slightly-mandatory grinding is even fun. That's saying so much.Perhaps the most touching, is that it's a fully realized PC port. A game built with a JRPG engine has full mouse and keyboard support. Sure it seems like it would be standard for PC ports to have such things, but seeing a lack of mouse control in recent PC ports like DMC: Special Edition, it's hard not to feel grateful that the developers worked so hard to make mouse and keyboard work everywhere in this game. The amount of love they must have for this game must rival mine. And it does not surprise me, because it's extremely easy to fall in love with this game. You will have to practice the keyboard controls a bit (it took me a little bit to find out that Page Up and Page Down helps you aim your spells in combat, and Page Up re-centers your camera when exploring dungeons) but it won't take long, and the game's turn-based nature is very conducive with this control scheme, ensuring you have as much time as you need to figure out how, and where, to aim your spells. Give it a while, and you won't notice any difference in speed from casting a spell at the right position using a keyboard or a controller.And to top it all off; my girlfriend gifted me this game and all of its dlc's. Even if it wasn't such an amazing game, it would be worth appreciating simply because she got it for me. But it turned out to be my personal game of the year. Deandra, I love you, and I can't thank you enough for giving me this art, and I can't thank Compile Heart and Idea Factory enough for creating it.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Game: Max PayneGenre: Third Person ShooterDeveloper: Remedy EntertainmentSystem: PC (Steam)Total Score: 84/100Value Score: 8.4/10• Story: 10/10o The story of Max Payne takes place in New York in the year 2001, however the story begins three years prior to the events of the current game. Max Payne is a police detective part of the NYPD, he had a great life going, a beautiful wife, a new baby girl and a good job. However everything comes at a price and his story is about to go down in a grim path. One day his wife and daughter were murdered in cold blood at his home in New Jersey, he quickly dispatched the murders however his family was slaughtered. A few years later in the year 2001 Max Payne's search for the real murders continues until he finally reaches a clue which will lead him to the right direction however what he might find will be far bigger than he had anticipated and will initiate his fall.• Characters: 8/10o Max Payne's characters are like from a usual Noire style film or a Mafia film better put as an example. All from the character designs towards the voice over, it feels like you are watching one of the great 1900s movies about gangs which is a pretty nice touch to the environment and the storyline. The best character of course is the main character, so much personality even through his narrator dialog that he speaks in majority of the game. The character designs for the enemies however may feel generic at first but the amount of different enemies is actually pretty big for a somewhat short game. The characters are best represented in the noire style film comic that is displayed throughout the entire game and that is how the storyline is shown to the player.• GamePlay: 10/10o Max Payne is your typical third person shooter, you play as Max Payne who can get access to all sorts of weapons and tools ranging from pistols, shotguns, rifles, grenade launchers, snipers, baseball bats, grenades and Molotov bottles. You also have a special ability called "Bullet Time" (which can be used with the right mouse button) which slows down the game enough for the player to do attacks against enemies with their weapon allowing you to do Matrix like moves in the process for precise aiming. You also get access to various amounts of Pain pills which can be used to heal your health. You'll be breaking through carts, boxes, cases and all sorts of instruments to get these items which will help you kill enemies. Enemies will usually pop up without warning, you can sneak up to them or even snipe them at different occasions. You'll also be prompted to start cutscenes showcasing the game's narration through a noire style film comic which you can replay with use of the F1 button. Pressing the F5 button saves the game F9 will load the game back to the previous state it was saved. You can press the number keys to switch weapons easily or roll the mouse wheel. Pressing space will let you jump and the usual WASD combo is used for walking in default mode. Pressing R will allow you reload ammo to your weapon and pressing E will allow you to search objects with exclamation points above them when you get near them or allow you to zoom in for sniping a enemy with a sniper rifle. You also have a arrange of difficulty modes which can only be accessed once you finish the default normal mode and have access to the credits automatically.• Graphics: 7/10o Max Payne's graphics at the time were in the mixture of N64/PSX and PS2/Dreamcast graphics. Although majority of the character sprites look like they were cardboard character cut outs from the WWF/WWE games, the environment, cutscenes and the narrator scenes were nicely done and matches with the story quite well. Adding a bleak color and setting to the storyline was well made and feels like you are in a movie. If you enjoyed games like GTA III you will not have any worries with this game.• Sound: 10/10o The voice acting in this game is simply amazing and you can tell they chose the best actors for the game. It really feels like you are watching a classic mafia/gang movie from the late 1900s. The sound effects from weapons, attacks, noises from the environment and characters were nicely made and was a rare thing back in its time.• Music: 7/10o The music may not be as good as other games but when it does play it brings up the mood and makes players feel like adrenaline rushing through their veins while fighting against enemies. Although majority of the game will not have any music unless you are fighting through a midway battle against the main enemies or against a "Boss" like character, the intro music plays during cutscenes giving a eerie feeling to the already gloomy and iconic movie like environment.• Length: 6/10o Max Payne 1 on PC is divided into three parts with about 7-9 chapters each with a prologue in the beginning as well to introduce the player to what the situation is. The main storyline should take you about 7 hours to complete and if you keep exploring through the terrain of the levels and areas within the game it could even take you up to 13 hours.• Replay Value: 6/10o Max Payne's replay value mostly comes from two extra levels which can be gained once you get to a higher difficulty. The game includes three additional difficulties which two of them can be unlocked at the end of the first playthrough and the third after a playthrough with one of the higher difficulty modes. The two extra levels adds extra challenge and little to no actual storyline however but it is great for replay value wise for players who want more hours squeezed out in this game.• Player Value: 10/10o Max Payne for the PC is an amazing experience. If you enjoyed noire type films, mafia style themed movies or action pack movies you will enjoy this game. To add to the amazing storyline and characters, you have an amazing gameplay system implemented that gives you more control to the game than most other shooters which also paves way towards future shooting games. Get this game on Steam now which is available with its sequel. You will not regret it.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Max Payne. Voted to be in the top 10 happiest video game characters ever created, now in my book monotone voice acting along with a man who has lost everything quicker than he can pop some painkillers, is an impeccable decision by Remedy. This man has no reason to be happy, and anyone who disagrees just imagine having your baby daughter and wife murdered by drug fueled thugs!Moving on to gameplay, this game revolutionised third person shooters in general. It showed us that amongst all the happiness of Banjo Kazooie or any other animal based adventure game, that there was an ignored darkness lurking in reality and Remedy made a brave move by showing us that darkness. Moving back on topic again, The introduction to the slo-mo dive shooting mechanic really turned the tables in the event of a shootout, you could carefully pick out your targets and try to dispatch of them with care as you dive through the air. Now don't get me wrong this mechanic was not perfected straight off the bat, it was actually quite clunky in some situations, but all credit for actually bothering with something new for once rather than just another generic third-person shooter.Let us swiftly move onto story, Well let's just say that it's not the most complex idea in the book, but nonetheless that's not always a bad thing. Basically Max returns home after a night working at the NYPD only to find a group of drug fueled thugs have broke into his house and he ends up seeing his baby daughter and wife brutally murdered, so Max being Max bent on revenge swears to kill those who did this too him, leading him down a road he was never prepared for. All in all I thoroughly enjoyed meeting new characters and having them involved with the story, it made it seem like Max wasn't so alone after all.Finally we move onto the biggest feature of the game the main man himself - MAX PAYNE. Boy oh boy 80% of the reason I love this game so much is down to this man. Let me begin by saying that whilst you are playing the game you feel as much emotion as Max feels meaning you can relate to him on a whole other level. You genuinely feel sorry for this poor son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ and this actually makes you want to unravel the mystery about the fate of his family as well.So for christ's sake if you are unsure whether or not to get the franchise this game introduces it exceptionally well!7/10

												"I don't know about angels, but it's fear that gives men wings."Video game storytelling at its peak. This is a legend among classics where film-noir meets mythology meets late 90's early 2000's action. Holding one of the most quotable main characters in gaming history, if you care in the slightest about game narratives this is something that you need to play through. Despite its age, Max Payne's gameplay never fails to entertain. Although dated now, this game was revolutionary upon release and the second and third installments - although good on their own - can't compare to this relic.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												This game is a gritty third-person shooter about a police officer called Max Payne. The game has bullet time elements which allow Max to pull of incredible kills and survive against the odds. The game starts with the murder of your wife and child, and doesn't ever get any happier, even at the end. The gameplay is decent but nothing too amazing due to it's age. The game is interesting, exiting, and fun as well as very engaging too. Though at points the grittiness of the game make it a bit horrible to look at, it was an artistic decision. The game has comic book style cutscenes which are nice to look at and read through and carry the story along brilliantly and much better than a "normal cutscene" would have been able to at the time of the game's release. The game is stands up to this date and you must play through it if you want to play the sequels as it allows you to not only see but feel the pain Max has been through to get where he is in the sequels. The AI in this game are difficult even though you start it on the easiest setting, but the quick save feature allows you to get round this difficulty with ease. The sound on the game isn't perfect but is bearable. It's level design is very good and allows exploring for any extra supplies such as guns, ammo, and pain killers if needed. The character of Max Payne and the story of his life full of pain and suffering are both brilliant and a real experience to go through. The graphics in this game are certainly impressive for the time of release and are no issue at all.The game can be difficult at times and there are more engaging games out there that can keep you playing for longer sessions at a time but this game is overall pretty decent.9/15 - "Fairly decent gritty third-person shooter about pain and suffering"

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												It's Max Payne, what more needs to be said?The only question you should have is "Does it hold up?" and yes, it does. After some start-up tinkering to fix the sound (check the Steam forum for that fix) it will run without a hitch from then on. You can play it in a 16:9 resolution but I wouldn't recommend that as it will stretch the textures so you end up with Fat Max Payne. The story is still great, the voice overs are great, and the gameplay is very punishing, yet satisfying. The moratorium on "Bullet Time™" across the industry as of late helps make the 2001 gameplay of Max Payne still feel refined, satisfying and innovative. Prepare to die. A lot. The game can be frustrating at times, but it never made me want to stop, but rather use my next life to try and correct my prior mistake, and rewriting history like that is ultimately satisfying to the end. The graphics also hold up really well for a game nearly 15 years old. Environmental textures aren't always the sharpest, but a lot still look better than I expected for a game this old when I ran it in 1600x1200 resolution, and the models look defined and sharp.Highly recommended.

 Broken The reason I am giving this game a bad review is NOT because it is a bad game. It's pretty much unanimous that this game is a great one. The issue is that if you have Windows 7 IT WILL (most likely) NOT WORK. Neither will Max Payne 2 for that matter. If you look at the compatability it even says that it will only work on XP. I bought the bundle and was sorely disappointed to find out that I couldn't even run either of them in compatability mode. Now that I have said that, some people have been able to run these games no problem in compatability mode and there are a myriad of fixes you can try if that fails. The reason I am not recommending this game is because I spent an entire day trying to get these games to work somehow and tried all if not most of those fixes and nothing worked and now these games are just sitting in my library and I just sigh in sadness and regret whenever I see them.I mean you can buy it and who knows? Maybe you can get it to work? It's really just a gamble to buy this game. In my opinion it is not worth the headache and you're better off emulating it somehow or buying it for your PS2. Unless of course you have Windows XP, in which case go for it! I just wish someone had warned me that this game is so hard to run on Windows 7 and that's why I made this review, hopefully it will help you guys.

												A game that marked my first years as a gamer. Definately recommending it. Epic dark themed story, full of sarcastic jokes of a cop that was in the bad place at a bad time, with his family paying the consequences. Now he has dedicated his life to seek the true responsibles for the loss of his loved beings. Secret government departments, greed and power addicted villians AND BULLET TIME!!!! Awesome game mechanics and the introduction (in its time) of this one (bullet time) in particular. Even though the graphics seem (and are indeed) old, everything else compensates it. If you are reading this DON'T MISS IT!! Afraid of the compatibility issues?? NO PROBLEM. I was afraid too when I tried my luck and bought it here praying for it to work with the simple steps I read about. In the Max Payne directory of steam: Right click to maxpayne.exe, properties, compatibility tab, select compatibility mode Windows 98/ME and Run as Administrator = MAGIC. -Sound problems? There's an easy fix online and it's a major thread (resolved) topic on the community hub of this game. Google the fix or just click on the link given in the forums, WORKS LIKE A CHARM. -People saying "NOT WORKING ON MULTICORE PROCESSORS" and "NOT COMPATIBLE WITH AMD VIDEO CARDS" or "NOT WORKING ON x64 OS SYSTEMS" HAHA NICE TRY!! I'm running it on Windows 7 Ultimate x64, Core 2 Quad 2.83 GHZ and an AMD HD5770 so :P DO NOT MISS THIS MASTERPIECE. As an extra, there are a lot of GOD-BLESSED AWESOME mods out there. I almost cried when I tried the Kung-Fu mod... its a MUST have, replay value  x 100000. I hope this helped you decide buying this awesome game. DO IT. WHY ARE YOU STILL READING THIS???? BUY IT.

												Max Payne is a very stiff, very bland, punishingly difficult game. Unless it comes as a gift, you are a hardcore fan of this series or in a bundle I would not recomend buying it. Music is terrible. You get two options (not really options) elevator music while nothing happens with the sound of your massive feet slapping over and over while you traverse the city or "tense" music when there are enemies nearby which you wont even be able to listen to since you will be ripping your hair out from the dreadful gameplay.BUYER BEWARE: Many gamers that have bought this game literally CANNOT play it because of compatibility issues, glitches, etc.Not recomended unless you are a fan of the caracter or series. Honestly I was bored out of my mind passing the halfway point in the game.The only thing that brings any justice in the game is the bullet time which is basically the "power or ability" in which Max slows down time to be able to shoot while jumping, at many enemies. Still doesnt make the game fun or worthwhile.BTW: no checkpoints, terrible ai/animations, bad grafics, puzzles that make absolutely no sense.3/10 PLAY AT YOUR OWN RISK

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												My review can simply be summed up as 'Thumbs down with the Steam Version' 'Thumbs up to the game design itself'.As noted by many in the Steam forums. The Steam version has sound compatibility issues and there is no sound to either cut scenes or background music, even though the sound works with everything else for example bullet fire and npc dialogues. So why the developers continue to argue for $10.00 when this product is faulty on Steam is a criminal payne. The developers can be found here http://remedygames.com/I'm not sure why this was nominated as a game with one of the best stories. Its definitely a long stretch from that with its over the top corny pictures and cheap budget voice acting, however the game is definitely fun as a fps which harbors a unique cinematic matrix trick at your characters disposal.Made back in 2001 the graphics are somewhat dated, but the game is still entertaining and will give you a similar adventure feeling comparable to that of Half Life. It's the clever level designs and the many secret places and passages that they hide that make it a delight to explore. Personally I recommend the youtube walkthrough by countduncan if you want to find many of the secrets. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL3cSywp2PAPGempVYWo9CioXBQnRVWVDSThe game has 4 modes, easy, medium, hard and a time mode. Even easy is really difficult in comparison to some of the games of today and thanks to the F5 quick save at your disposal you will be practically using it after every gun shot. The time mode is just a get out of my way, mow everything down while you sprint, brandishing two uzi's or an automatic shotty. However even this is really, really, really tricky also.So what is the story? The story involves Max Payne who 3 years ago arrived home to find his wife and child murdered by 3 addicts hyped up on a new drug called 'V'. After the funeral he takes up the offer of an old friend Alex Balder and leaves NYPD to work with the DEA and try and get this new drug off the streets. Working covertly undercover, Max Payne is set up as an operative inside the Punchinello crime family after they get a serious lead pointing their attention to an underboss known as Jack Lupino transporting the drug. This operation is so tight lipped that only Max's true identity is only known by 2 people, that is Alex Balder and B.B who is also an administrative DEA.B.B eventually gets a tip that something BIG is going down at Roscoe Street Subway station and informs both Max and Alex to get down there and investigate. Little do they know it's a trap which exposes Max Paynes true identity to the Punchinello family. Max knowing there is no where to hide and that a hit has now been placed on his head, decides to go all Humphrey Bogart and hunt down the Don of this family himself. On his journey he will meet a variety of colorful under-bosses and assassins which he will need to take out of the equation and cater for first.Eventually he learns more about this V drug how it was originally designed and tested by the government to try and enhance the performance and morale of soldiers during the gulf war. However the project was quickly halted in 1995 when the test results showed damning mental side effects. Problem was certain high ranking officials saw potential in this drug and decided to keep testing and manufacturing it in secret. Not long after that Max learns what connection the 3 addicts had to do with his wife and why she needed to die. Armed with the new revelation of what really happened and slightly influenced with the invigorating power of V on himself he tracks down all those responsible and kills them.I guess in a nutshell because the story has some aspects similar to the well known and publicized MKUltra experiments the CIA performed unknowingly on many of the public, it often gets nominated as a 'great story', but seriously nothing still quite beats the original...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_MKUltraSince the Steam version is completely broken you may want to download a completely working sound version for yourself here... mediafire/download/oa8aeji5j70lh8z/Max+Payne++1+No+Sound+Fix.exe (just put www. before mediafire and .com after media fire)Just create a steamapps folder named Max Payne and install it in that and then run exe direct or add it to your steam account. It's a fun piece of gaming art.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												If you had asked me in 2001 what I thought of Max Payne, you would have gotten an incredibly enthusiastic, positive answer. I freakin loved Max Payne, everything about it at the time was mindblowing, it was the first game to have competently done slo-mo, the storyline (at the time) was not only fairly dark and compelling, but also funny and self-aware, in a way much more subtle and enjoyable than something like Duke Nukem 3D. Visually mindblowing, with intensely cool effects like bullets being modelled, shell casings being modelled (dropping to the floor as you filled enemies with lead) and real world locations with explosive set-pieces and action.At the time, it was absolutely mindblowing.But now, it is pap. It is infuriatingly dated, it's like your grandpa who won't shut up about Vietnam or the Korean War or whatever and at first it was cool when you're a kid but now you're just depressed at his psychological devesation at the death of his friends, what? Nothing, nevermind.Anyway, the root of the problem is that Max Payne's level design is absolutely donkey dongs, the AI behavior is entirely scripted so basically every moment of the game can be memorized, and you'll HAVE to memorize the more difficult segments, as they are difficult for exclusively arbitrary and crap reasons. Since Max takes locational damage like any other enemies, your dives should almost exclusively be backwards with his feet facing forward, since diving forward is welcoming Max's instantaneous, welcomed release from his hellish torment of a life as bullets pile-drive his face and you get to watch in glee like you're some kind of kid from a special needs program who absolutely loves WWE. But this mechanic is the biggest reason why this game is so frustrating, an enemy sprays you in the chest? Fine, you'll like lose most of your healthbar, but you'll live, a single shot in the head? Instadead. Max lies down with a look like his bunger screamed flaming diarrheatic doodoo in his moment of death.Now this wouldn't be so bad if it weren't for a few things, one, this game loves deathtraps, and they aren't just environmental hazards like a door exploding or whatever, they'll be enemies that are scripted to run around a corner immediately, throwing a grenade down stairs (which there is only ever one correct direction to run away from, anything else gets you killed) and since the enemies' reactions are absolutely pearl beyond belief, you end up getting a face full of buckshot while they mug at you goofily with their weird rictus grins of stupidity. So you basically quick-save nonstop, running into an area, hoping you don't get riddled with really slow moving bullets (the physics in this game are weird) try to kill the enemies through a combination of manual bullet-time and shoot dodges (by the way, manual bullet-time is not set by default, make sure to go into the key bindings and set a key for it) without having a stray bullet slap you in the noggin. If you die, quick load, if you don't, move to the next door, quick-save, then repeat endlessly until the end of the game.Mooks also take about a dozen bullets to kill, and since weapons spray in indiscernible trajectories most of the time, you can't consistently land headshots, even with the most accurate weapons in the game, like the Desert Eagle or Colt Commando, the only gun that always lands its shot is the Sniper Rifle, and that gun sucks crap in most of the game's areas and prevents you from shoot dodging.Oh, and speaking of shoot dodging, it's almost always a bad idea, it looks cool, but you're pretty much better off only using manual bullet-time, running around, instead of shoot dodge, since shoot dodge only allows you a very limited amount of shots before you're prevented from firing anymore as you lie on the ground, giving enemies plenty of time to kill you murderously or run over and pee in your mouth or a host of other possibilities. It's just annoying constantly hearing "HEYA" and having your brain squished out of your skull. Enemies will literally wait around corners and without hesitation pound you to death as soon as you turn the corner, even shoot-dodging won't save you most of the time.There's also just a ton of annoying segments in the game that force you to do platforming or climb up pillars or etc. and Max's movement is so stiff and unnatural, his jump so iffy and weird, that oftentimes you'll fall to your death or stumble around like a drunken ape as you shuffle on pipes and other pieces of junk.At least the level design is straight forward enough that you never get lost, which is saying something for a game from this era, old school shooters used to think sending you into a monochromatic labyrinth of banality was amazing level design (see Unreal/Daikatana/etc.)I still love the story, it's unapolagetically ridiculous and the writing has a lot of character and personality to it, Max's character arch is interesting and well developed, and there's a lot of funny dialogue between idling enemies. The comic book segments are well done and feature a lot of beautiful to look at grimaces and weird faces from Sam Lake. Ambient sound is great, the music is fantastic, the guns sound wonderful, basically, the production values of this game have held up well, they're not stunning like they used to be, but for the most part the presentation of this game is acceptable and doesn't hold the game back by modern standards.But it's just such a frustrating slog to play, there's very little rhyme or reason to it, you can be a great FPS gamer and yet most of your encounters are just down to luck, like that idiot Leprechaun from those crap Leprechaun movies, where he's murdering people in really dumb ways and saying completely stupid crap, I hate those movies and I hate that idiot Leprechaun. Just like I hate the encounter design of this game.Hell, even Max says it himself at one point, as you assault a mob boss's mansion, it has nothing to do with skill, or playing your cards right, it's all chaos and luck.That's a very apt thing to say Max, you sexy boy.Max Payne 2 and 3 are fortunately, much much better games, and I highly recommend them, but I can't really recommend MP1 as its gameplay design is archaic and frustrating. It's a shame, and I haven't even said anything about the dead baby dungeon and Twizzler tight ropes and Max's wife screaming at him because she burnt the roast or something.Anyway, I wish I could still like Max Payne 1 like I did back in the day, but unfortunately I have to sensually whip off my rose-colored glasses and call it as it is. This game is straight doodie.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Story pros and cons:+Deep story filled with some of the best narration I've heard- props to Remedy+Comic style cutscenes are unique and help give an artistic vision to the story+ Chilling concept revolving around the murder of his wife and child due to madmen on a drug called Valkyr+ Character cracks some light-hearted jokes even in his time of desperation making the situation for the player more comfortable and helps with character development-The jokes that Max Payne gives sometimes makes it hard to take him seriously-Disturbing drug induced sequences-Plot ending was somewhat anti-climatic and the last part was compared to the rest of the game too easy (not even considered a boss fight)-Some character voices are annoying to say the leastGamplay pros and cons: +Bullet time is a an interesting and well designed mechanic+Large selection of weaponry+State of the art (for its time) particle system when bullets impact objects+Interaction with objects provides immersion+Weapons are sorted nicely in the upper part of the screen and fits with the rest of the UI. +Enemies have conversations and sometimes interact with Payne's actions-Some weapons are underpowered such as the shotguns (excluding the jackhammer), especially the dual barrel shotgun -Sniper rifles are almost useless because enemies even on the easiest difficulty are extremly accurate with weapons like shotguns and uzi's and most of the areas in this game aren't large enough to make use of it- Grenades have a deadly area of effect, even standing a few metres away from the blast you're lucky not to have a large chunk of your health taken away. - Enemies are insanly accurate with the weapons, sometimes they'll use shotguns and manage to hit you from several metres away continously and destroy you with them. The player however somehow can't manage to kill enemies with a dual barrel shotgun at close range. Go figure!-Uzi's do more damage close range than shotguns!? *scratches head* they can also take multiple enemies out so once you get the Uzi the shotguns become almost instantly unreliable-Bosses are just buffed up in terms of health, they don't provide any interesting mechanics or tactic behind them. Some of the bosses are so ridicolous that even with multiple headshots, blasts from grenades etc still won't kill them on the easiest difficulty.-Easiest difficulty is for some reason stupidly hard. I can't tell you how many times I've died and had my trigger finger on the quick saves.-No auto saves. Sound pro's and cons:+Great gun sound effects+Narration is crisp and clear considering its age+Somewhat humerous death sounds+Memmorable Soundtrack-Lack of sound options means that you can't adjust the volume of the voice, sound effects and music seperatly-Voice during comic style cutscenes are louder than in game-No voice/music sound problems on Windows 7 and 8 requires you to go through the trouble of patching it.Overall this game offers what looks like a simple plot which is executed rather well and complex and the narration is on par with Alan Wake which is also made by Remedy, I wholeheartedly recommend you go play that game over this one if you're looking for a very strong voice narration driven game because while this one provides that, it does so at the cost of mediocre gameplay, fustrating difficulty, absurd bosses and unbalanced weaponry. I haven't played Max Payne 2 yet so I can't recommend that game over this one.With all that being said, I give the game a fair score of 6.5/10. There's fun to be had here, just remember that this game has aged and not necessarily in a good way.

												Max Payne is a bonafide and award winning noir classic released in 2001. The game centers around a NYPD cop working undercover in the Valkyr-drug smuggling mafia seeking answers after he got his family killed. As the story unravels, Max becomes the most wanted guy by the mafia and the NYPD and discover what is hiding behind the drug Valkyr.The story is presented to the player using comic novels artifacts which sometimes resembles Frank Miller's Sin City. Cutscenes are entertaining to watch and sucks you into it with a noir narrative. I wish Max Payne got his own comic book, because the writing is second to none immersive. There is a heavy influence of nordic mythos which adds to the bigger picture.I love the level design. Although is set mostly in a stormy, snowy and dark NY or inside some buildings, it nevers gets repetitive. You'll be looking all over the place for clues, guns and painkillers. Max Payne has one of the best level design I've ever seen in any game. You'll never forget about those nightmare levels and shootings at the Ragna Rock night club.The music is beautiful. It has a dark and dense mood to it, the one you'd expect from detective stories. The synth sounds go really with the ambient sounds.The gameplay is absolutely fun. The game introduces an innovative (at the time) bullet time and bullet dodge mechanics. This is a hard game, although there is some automatic health regen don't expect miracles. You'll be craving for painkillers through out the whole game. Also, a word of advice, DON'T save if you're not sure if you're still in the middle of a bullet fest.I can assure you the game aged gracefully.Writing a positive review about an award winning game that eventually became the cornerstone of the 2000's age of gaming feels just like another brick in the wall. It's just another one in the bag of thousand positive reviews Max Payne got through the years.A must have for ANY gamer.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Max Payne is a really unique game, a rare gaming gem.Back in 2001 it was a revolutionary game.You are Max Payne, a man with nothing to lose. Your family is murdered by drug addicts, you are deep undercover in the underworld of New York. Then, your cover is blown, and the cops thinks you are one of the bad guys.The game itself is a 3rd person shooter, with it´s best feature being the ability to slow down time. This feature added depth to the vicious shootouts, and the destruction caused by the bullets could be apreciated in detail.Simply put, there were nothing like that around. It borrowed many elements from The Matrix, including slow motion action sequences and many of its locations.You just have to keep moving and keep shooting every single enemy (there is one scort mission, but it´s fairly short and thankfully not frustating at all), It could be repetitive in theory, but the shootings are so fun it never gets old.Dodging bullets while firing your duals berettas couldn´t be more rewarding.The story is surprisingly deep for a game of it´s kind. It involves drugs, infanticide, madness, evend the russian mafia plays it´s part, and high echelon corporate conspiracy. It´s just awesome, and told in a very dark tone.Ultimately, it´s a tale of revenge of a broken man, alone and desperate, with no higher moral, no savior cause or anything.It aged very well. The mechanics are still fun, the graphics might seem a bit bulky and outdated, but there are some really good textures and nice particle effects that still makes it good looking in movement. Also, any cheap PC can run it with max settings without problems.If you dig deep, you can also find some very interesting mods, adding weapons and levels that explore more of the great shooting mechanics.10/10Don´t miss it.

												Despite its age, Max Payne remains a fun shooter with an interesting story. The game suffers, however, from some clunkiness because of when it was made and its attempts to have occasional platforming sections, that are sometimes frustrating and irritating to play. Some of them are important to the story, but could've been done without having the player make precise jumps with imprecise movement controls. There were also frequent stutters in cutscenes and keyboard lock-ups when I played (Max would be stuck in place or stuck moving or diving in one direction). Despite some of the minor issues, the game holds up because of good encounter design, fun shooting mechanics and great writing, especially in Max's thoughts. The frequent metaphors and allusions give it an almost literary quality. Recommended, but might feel a little too dated for some.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I finally found my way to "Max Payne 3", and as preparation before the third installment, I decided to revisit the first two games to brush up on the story, get in the right mood, and simply to see if they still hold up as well as I remembered them. They do. In fact, they're even better, with me being a more mature gamer and properly appreciating the work of art that is the MP franchise.MP was the game which introduced bullet time to gaming in a way that worked. Not only as a gimmick, but rather as a core gameplay element. Without it, and without using is smartly on top of that, you'd get nowhere. And be warned, MP doesn't pamper you and take you by the hand. It kicks you in the butt and shoves you right into the thick of it. That is to say, the game is H-A-R-D. Very, very hard. Even on the lowest (and default) difficulty setting bad guys ambush you all the times, they shoot very straight, and can mow you down in a couple of well placed hits. The quick save button will be your best friend (and occasionally you'll end up using it more than the 'shoot' button). MP is truly an unforgiving shooter, requiring a tactical approach to every gunfight: where you have to pick your targets carefully, when to roll, when to evade, where you'll land afterwards, who'll be remaining standing... otherwise - GAME OVER.And then, there's the story - a hard-boiled noir crime drama told through comic book style panels, with superb voice acting and an amazingly well-written script. Even if the gameplay weren't so fun, MP would still have you in its grip solely because of the plot.To conclude: an all-around amazing game, still incredibly fun even if its age does show. Despite that, it blows the majority of modern shooters out of the water. Needles to say, a must have title. I don't trust a gamer who doesn't like MP.

Posted: March 1, 2013
												Max Payne a man that lost everything and has nothing but the truth to find, a truth he wants, but sometimes the truth hurts, this is not the case. Max comes home from his job as a NYPD officer to find his loving wife and his baby daughter Rose dead, the people who killed them still in the house. He kills them and starts on a downward spiral trying to find what happened to his family.The game starts off straight forward enough, as far as a third person shooter goes it did two things 10 years ago when it came out, it set a standard for third person shooters, and it introduced bullet time. The only thing that sepreates you from the NPC's of Max's universe is the ability to heal and the ability to slow time, past that you are just as human, you will get frustrated. You will hate rounding a corner at full health and dying to a single bullet, but that is made up quickly with the ability to save anywhere, one tap of F5 and you save your state.The game does a good job of telling Max's story, you play him through his quest to find answers and this leads you to many different places, the levels all vary heavily, they rarely feel samy unless it a particulary long level, and that only happened once to me. The weapons list is short, you could drag it out if you included the dual weild function on some of the guns, but even then it's only the same gun in each hand, so they built the game to be simple but delivery very well.Most of Max Payne is focused on the narration that Max gives you and the story, it's different, enemies will talk to each other before you enter a room, some insight into thier lives or views, favorite movies and so on. The game is amazingly immersive and gives you alot to keep going, it's not afraid to break the fourth wall a couple of times to sell a few key points in the game, so it often adds to the immersion rather than taking it away.If i had to say one thing to sell Max Payne to someone is, if you like third person shooters, and want a good story, this is it. If you want a good game to play that passes the time and will give you some awesome noir quotes then this is the game for you.

Posted: July 16, 2015
												This is one of those special-place-in-my-heart games that elicits some kind of catharsis every time it's played.  The setting, gameplay, soundtrack, dialogue, artwork - it all comes together in this strange culmination of dark justice.   Max Payne loses in the end, whether he wins or not.  He's doomed from the start, and a lot of games don't torture their heroes this much.  So from the beginning you're in this nothing-to-lose mentality alongside our protagonist.  The mechanics even support this idea, as you can restart from the last point of death if you mash the quicksave button like an underlying arc from a Lost episode.  Events replay like you went back in time a few seconds prior to your blundered encounter and decided to duck left instead of right.  The gaming community criticized this feature when it released all those years ago, and people are still kind of iffy on it because of its linear drive.  This game really is a comic come to life.  The setting is as much a character as Max is, rife with loneliness and torment - slowly picked apart by what can only be described as a 100-year winter.  New York City is the target of the Norse Gods' "♥♥♥♥-this-place-in-particular" ice beam of misery, effectively isolating Max and a thousand goons to do glorious battle in Thunderdome 2.0.  The reason this game is and will always be timeless is because you don't need to inject yourself into 2001 to appreciate this title for all that it is.  It's a story that can be told over and over.

I own the game on multiple platforms and have just completed it on Steam.Max Payne is a third-person shooter action thriller that centers on the NYPD Detective Max Payne, who attempts to avenge the murder of his family. It features a gritty neo-noirstyle and uses graphic novel panels (with voice-overs) in place of animated cutscenes to narrate the game, as it draws inspiration from hard-boiled detective novels by authors like Mickey Spillane. The gameplay is heavily influenced by the Hong Kong action cinema genre, particularly the work of director John Woo, and it was one of the first games to feature the bullet time effect popularized by The Matrix.While the graphics are now dated the game is still enjoyable to play and the story and voice acting is fantasic.I would highly recommend this game. Don't forget to check out my guide for Windows 10 support which also works for Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne.10/10

												Now this game. My oh my, this game.I love Max Payne with all of my heart. It's one of my all time favourite games. Allow me to tell you why.-The story is something straight out of a Noir Cop film, so gritty and thrilling. It's so fun to watch the story unravel with twists, turns and suspense.-The gunplay is amazing, it's the main thing that makes this game so fun. The fact that you start of with Berettas and as you progress through the game you come across a wide array of weapons to use on more powerful enemies is sweet candy to my mind. -The dialogue (mainly Max's) is so chilling at times. Max's voice and delivery of his lines makes him such an entertaining and deep protagonist to play as. He is such a great character who you can sympathise with.-This game has a tendency to catch you off guard. At the start of every 3 parts of the game, it changes it's pace from an over the top action thriller to a psychological horror. The nightmare sequences in this game can really catch you off guard and disturb the hell out of you.- And who can forget the bullet time? The feature that this game in infamous for. Inspired and taken out of John Woo films, this feature allows you to slow down time and jump through the air to dodge bullets and kill your enemies in style. Bullet time never gets old, no matter how many times you play through the game.I give this game a 10/10. I would recommend Max Payne to everyone and anyone (unless you're one of those idiots who are turned off by old graphics).Buy the game. It is definitely worth £5.99

												Max Payne is a third person action shooter that focuses heavily on gun play and storytelling. It was probably the first game that pulled off bullet time succesfully and opened the way to other games like F.E.A.R. to improve it and modernize it. The creators of Max Payne were obviously inspired by the popular action movie of that time, The Matrix, to design the shooting mechanics and the overall action theme of Max Payne.You play as Max Payne, an NYPD detective who sets on avenging his wife's and childs' death by the mafia that is connected with a powerful drug. As the story progresses, you unravel the darker side of the story that led to the loss of your family. The story is presented through graphic novel slides with voice over as narrative. I have to say that there are some really talented voice actors taking part in this game. The production team used many of its members to pose as the characters Max Payne and it clearly shows that they had a lot of fun doing so. The visuals are obviously dated compared to modern games and some of the basic features like mission obvectives are missing. For its time however, Max Payne was way ahead in both presentation and most importantly gameplay. It has a noire style of art design and an overall mature and dark theme which is a rare thing in our days.The gameplay is heavily focused on gun play which at some point gets kinda repetitive and almost boring but the bullet time effect is keeping things interesting. What is really annoying though is the difficulty level. I have never played such a hard shooter like this one before. It is so unfairly hard at some points that it forces you to abuse the save load option and memorize the opponent placement. So, you will die a lot in this game. This is an unforgivingly hard game that WILL punish you! The music isn't memorable, except for the main theme which is played through most of the game but all the songs fit with the tone and the dark theme of the game. What is memorable though is the voice of Max Payne and the whole narrative style. All in all, Max Payne is a challenging and an original for its time shooter with a classic revenge plot and a kickass protagonist that should be played by everyone who likes to go on a rampage killing junkies ,criminals and gangsters in style.
