												Max Payne is now an old game and this is more a recommendation for retro-gamers than anyone else since this game is quite dated in many areas. If you never looked into that title before and you love full-action-third-person-shooters, then you should give it a try because it does it quite well even compared to modern standards. The story has a good atmosphere despite being a classic « lone man seeks revenge » and it has the advantage of begin quite short (7-9hrs) which makes the retro-experience more bearable, especially if you plan to get into the series before or after Max Payne 3. The shooting is very satisfying for game of its age, since its a forerunner of the slow-motion matrix like « bullet time » that will later appear in F.E.A.R and other games. The games difficulty scales well as you progress and requires a good use and management of the bullet time mechanic which is extremely satisfying to play with. I'd recommend you pick it on sale, and that you look on steam forums for the sound patch to make it run on modern systems without issues.

												 A enjoyable, though somewhat dated third person shooter. You play as Max Payne, a NYPD-turned-DEA. The reason why? His wife and baby daughter was killed by druggies in the opening act of the game. The game's story is intriuging, as it deals with gangster's, betrayed cops, a secret society, and a corporate conspiracy, as well as Max's ultimate battle of fighting for his own well-being, all in very stylized comic book cutscences. Gameplay is a bit rough around the edges. Max Payne utilizes a bullet-time mechanic (Which you slow down time to dodge bullets akin to the matrix). Which helps alot- because you will have problems playing this as a straight laced 3rd person shooter. The aiming reticule is a primary offender of this, due to it being a small white dot in the middle of the screen. While it does help with immersion, it also makes it hard to aim at times. Thankfully, the game does have auto aim option, so it helps at times. The graphics- It's a game from 2001 so I can't say anything much- except the max payne model is scary. If I had rate it, it's a 8/10

												Despite its age, Max Payne remains a fun shooter with an interesting story. The game suffers, however, from some clunkiness because of when it was made and its attempts to have occasional platforming sections, that are sometimes frustrating and irritating to play. Some of them are important to the story, but could've been done without having the player make precise jumps with imprecise movement controls. There were also frequent stutters in cutscenes and keyboard lock-ups when I played (Max would be stuck in place or stuck moving or diving in one direction). Despite some of the minor issues, the game holds up because of good encounter design, fun shooting mechanics and great writing, especially in Max's thoughts. The frequent metaphors and allusions give it an almost literary quality. Recommended, but might feel a little too dated for some.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												Max Payne is, in some ways, a very unique game, and in many other ways it is just another third person shooter.It really depends on how you look at it. Stylistically, Max Payne is very engaging simply because you don't really see a lot of video games in a 'Noir'-kind of setting; I really have never played a game that is anything like Max Payne! If Noir is your thing and you love yourself some of those 'bloody revenge' stories in which one guy shoots his way through Mafia goons, you will probably not be disappointed by Max Payne...... That is, if you are sure that you can handle old-school shooters. For someone like me, this game aged very well actually, since I do not mind these older shooting mechanics which simply involve you evading fire rather than covering from it. It's a very simplistic game in that sense; don't expect any sort of depth. That's not a fault of the game, but I have talked to players who could not get into the game because they thought these mechanics lacked the intricacies of newer shooting games, like cover-mechanics and upgradable weapons. Not to mention, death is inevitable in Max Payne, mostly because Max can die in just a few gunshots (it's 'realistic' that way) and because he does not regenerate health on his own, so expect to be overwhelmed by enemies more often than not. Some may call it frustrating, but I call it challenging!Players who grew up playing games that force you to constantly quick save, quick load and just abuse the terrain to get cheap shots at enemies will enjoy this game no matter what, I would say. There isn't any variation in gameplay, all you do is search for ammo and health, and then shoot bad guys - Nothing more, nothing less. Either way, Max Payne is a classic.

Posted: March 22, 2015
												Max Payne was the originator of the film noir PC game. It combined elements of mystery intruige and shock very well. The opening scene in which Payne's wife and baby daughter are killed is more than enough to draw sympathy from gamers for him. It also acts as a fine incentive to blow the bad guys away.  The quest for justice and revenge is well told and the gameplay is well defined. The slow motion system allows players to create excellent moments of killing gangsters. The death poses are well choreographed and the set pieces are excellently designed. The music is a mixture of dynamic and classical. Max can't do any of the more innovative attack moves that Max Payne 3 introduced, but leaping forwards, to the side, backwards, rolling, are still available actions to perform.Before Max Payne, there were no games that were such effective pieces of transmedia. After, came all of them. They would not have been without Max Payne. Any action and Film Noir film fan will like this game. It is both fun to play and has a story that is very suspenseful, inventive and startling throughout.

Posted: March 31, 2015
												If my display picture is still displayed as "3d Realms", and my username is still the same, then some people may think my review is biased, so I'll give it to you straight.I'm guilty of not being able to play Max Payne until 2013. I also only became part of 3d Realms in 2015.That being said, I experienced the series firsthand early in the year, and it blew me away. I also have no "nostalgic" value for it, so my review is based on how I played it and experienced it as a gamer in modern times.This game is amazing, but takes some getting used to. Old-school health system, and extremely fast paced action make this an interesting title, where even low difficulty may take some modern gamers by surprise. The game is set in an awesome dark 1990s Noir setting with lots of interesting story to hear, and the awesome writing of the legendary Sam Lake (writer for Alan Wake by Remedy), coupled with the occasional bits of humour and witty one-liners.Lots of fast-paced gun action with bullet time makes for a gritty New York cop story, and definitely something worth experiencing. The story extends over the next two games (Max Payne 2 and Max Payne 3).If you want some oldschool (read: CHALLENGING) action for a change, this game is the one for you. Don't expect regenerating health and the ability to take 10000 bullets without dying whilst jelly jam runs down the screen. You will get shot, and you will probably die quite a few times on your first playthrough, but the experience is made fun by the awesome setting, bullettime action and the witty (and occasionally humourous) dialogue.I wouldn't recommend this if you want a more modern cover-based shooter with good graphics.

I also only became part of 3d Realms in 2015.That being said, I experienced the series firsthand early in the year, and it blew me away. I also have no "nostalgic" value for it, so my review is based on how I played it and experienced it as a gamer in modern times.This game is amazing, but takes some getting used to. Old-school health system, and extremely fast paced action make this an interesting title, where even low difficulty may take some modern gamers by surprise. The game is set in an awesome dark 1990s Noir setting with lots of interesting story to hear, and the awesome writing of the legendary Sam Lake (writer for Alan Wake by Remedy), coupled with the occasional bits of humour and witty one-liners.Lots of fast-paced gun action with bullet time makes for a gritty New York cop story, and definitely something worth experiencing. The story extends over the next two games (Max Payne 2 and Max Payne 3).If you want some oldschool (read: CHALLENGING) action for a change, this game is the one for you. Don't expect regenerating health and the ability to take 10000 bullets without dying whilst jelly jam runs down the screen. You will get shot, and you will probably die quite a few times on your first playthrough, but the experience is made fun by the awesome setting, bullettime action and the witty (and occasionally humourous) dialogue.I wouldn't recommend this if you want a more modern cover-based shooter with good graphics.

												Max Payne is a 3rd person shooter with a unique mechanic known as Bullet Time. While in this mode, Max leaps in a direction and slows down time allowing the player to take down multiple foes with ease. Damn, it is such an awesome feature. Great for stylish kills/takedowns.Story is absolutely amazing. You play as a New York cop who seeks revenge after such drug-fuelled thugs cross paths with you. As you go through the campaign, the tale gets darker and more intense though never losing it's humour. Ending was also great.Gameplay wise, it is one of the most fun action games I've played alongside Mafia - Lost City of Heaven (which is an incredible game). There is a lot of satisfaction in slowing down time and killing a whole bunch of dudes heavily armed with SMGs, shotguns and Berettas.Graphics are dated though that's to be expected as Max Payne came out in 2001, though is still serviceable.All in all, I'd recommend this game for all fans of action games with great stories.

												Even at 2013's standards, Max Payne is an enjoyable romp. With a great story, fun gunplay accompanied with the awesome revolutionary matrix-esque gameplay mechanics, it's 10 hours game time is a joy to blast through. The presentation of the game is quite stellar, especially with the comic-style storytelling, which I was pleasantly surprised to enjoy this style of storytelling. MP has its flaws however. The frequent interactions of objects that initates a cut-scene can annoyingly break the adrenaline flow, and the saving system can be quite infurating, if you've forgotten to manually save the game by pressing a specific key. Small flaws aside, Max Payne is still a great, fun game.  Recommended for newcomers to the series indeed. You may have sound issues during gameplay using current Windows operating systems, but thankfully there is a great fan patch that fixes the issue perfectly, so definitely grab that.

The drawback on this step is that only a few people will have a mouse with its own control panel.NOTE: Thompaine suggests that "If you don't have a special mouse with it's own control program, you can go into the "Mouse" control panel (Win7 classic CP) and uncheck the box labeled "Enhance pointer precision" under the "Pointer Options" tab", which helped him after installing the patch (Thank you!)MOUSE LAG FIX #2: Go to your Max Payne folder and run maxpayne.exe in compatibility mode for Windows 95. Posted: March 11, 2015
												An old review of mine, written in 2001. Unedited:I don’t know how to start. Really, I don’t. Maybe I should remind you about the movie known as Matrix, a movie that set a new standard in film industry, a movie that used breathtaking special effects never seen before. Slow motion, rotating camera, bullets ripping the air and the main character avoiding them… Fantastic, wasn’t it? There are some that didn’t like the movie, but I’ve never heard of a person who said that those effects weren’t amazing. This game is very similar to the Matrix, not only because of great effects but by its charm as well.I am pretty much sure that many, many gamers have at least heard of the Remedy’s game years ago. It’s been in the making for more than 4 years now and mutated from the first person shooter into the third person view action game. Yes, it was intended to be in first person view, but the game physics and the type of action didn’t allow such thing. Even the publisher has changed. It was supposed to be 3D Realms, but they “only” produced the game, which at the end was published by GOD Games, the company that’s actually younger than this product! That tells you a lot about the time needed to complete Max Payne, doesn’t it?Okay, lets get to the story. Actually, you can see the background story by playing through the introduction at the start of the game. Max is, or better to say was, an ordinary police officer, a New York PD detective working on the “usual” cases, solving the “usual” murders in the Big Apple. He was pretty good at what he did and was offered an “inside job” in the local mafia family. But Max had other plans in his life - a beautiful wife and a baby daughter. All he ever wanted was to be with them, but all that changed after they were brutally murdered by a group of junkies. Three years later, Max is on the inside job, in the Puncinello family. Only two people know his true identity, but after one of them gets killed while the other ones whereabouts become unknown. Max’ life is in real danger, especially after the mafia discovered him and launched a major offensive to capture and kill him. What a mess! Now both the police and the mafia are after our main character. It is your job to help poor Max’ survive in the unfriendly world as he learns a lot about the conspiracy, the drug lords, the people behind the murder of his family and military involvement in secret projects.As I said, the game is played from the third person view. You can see the complete Max in the middle of the lower part of the screen. The controls are pretty easy. You use arrow keys to move back and forth, or to strafe left and right. Mouse is used for turning left and right and firing the weapons. Other than that you only need to know the keys for weapon selection, slow motion (more about that later), use, jump and crouch. That’s all! There are no items to be carried around and used when needed. Actually, you can collect painkillers and get back some of lost health and that’s the only non-firing item that can be collected. Back to the main screen. Except for the Max, the bottom screen features the health bar presented as little, empty Max who fills with red color as he gets shot. Next to it is a small sand clock, which shows how much slow motion you have left (as I said, more about it later) and a number of painkillers left. Other than that there are weapon stats that show up in the top part of the screen, but only during the weapon selection.The graphics are simply gorgeous! A lot of attention is given to small details, which can be best seen during the shooting scenes between Max and multiple enemies. The play areas are always large, with a lot of rooms, furniture, buildings and other objects (unlike Oni, another fast paced action game with great gameplay but incredibly empty play areas!). Everything you see can be shot at. Not everything will be destroyed though, but holes from bullets or shotgun shrapnel will be there. Same goes with the sound. You will hear thugs talking between themselves about their wives, mother-in-law, guns, movies… That is of course until they see or hear you. I was amazed at duration of a show on the turned-on TV somewhere in one of the hotels in which game takes place. I just stood there, listened to the conversation in some soap opera, and they kept talking and talking and talking… so I turned off the darn TV! The speech was incredibly long!Now to the best part of the game – slow motion action or so-called bullet mode. Once you turn it on, the time slows down so both you and your opponents move slower, the bullets fired from the weapons move slowly so you can dodge them (Neo, Matrix was an expert in this). This slow-mo mode enables you to aim faster at your enemies as well, giving you an incredible advantage over the others. You know, it is pretty hard to explain how great this feature is, you simply have to see it to get the idea. Even the screenshots can’t show all the action. Heck, the screenshots can’t show anything at all! Another great feature is automatic zoom-in to the great kills. If you shoot a thug in an interesting way (a neck shot, multiple head shots and such), the game will zoom the enemy that was just shot, move the camera around him and show his death in a slow motion. Another thing that can not be fully described by words or screenshots!As Max advances further into the game, you will notice other great features. What I really like are the cut-scenes. Unlike most of the latest games, the cut-scenes in Max Payne are not movies or still pictures. They’re made as a comic strip, with hand-drawn Max, conversation bubbles and such. I like Max’ speeches and philosophy shown here!The downfalls of this game are a rarity. Aside from very linear story and lack of everything except shooting, the biggest disadvantage of Max Payne is – its shortness. It is possible to complete the whole game in just one day (if you do not explore a bit and actually play the game for straight 10 hours or so). Remedy tried to make it more fun by making several modes of playing through the game. Once you complete it in the normal mode (the only one available once you install the game), you will unlock the hard level and eventually the hardest (once you complete hard) and a time limited mode. But neither is really interesting to play since there are no big changes to the original story.Max Payne is a revolutionary product, no doubt about that. Bullet mode is simply fantastic and alone worth buying this game. The action is great, slow motion and zooming set new standards in action games, the story is brilliant… But it still seems to me like this title was an experiment, a prequel to the real thing. Only that can explain the shortness of such a great game. Should you buy it? Decide that yourself. If you’re looking for a game that’ll keep you busy for a long time then don’t, but if you’re eager to see something new and great then get it right away. You will not be disappointed!

												I rarely review games and only do so when I really REALLY enjoy the title.I've known about Max Payne for years, I've watched my brother play it over 8 years ago and actually picked it up before. I didn't play much of it because I remember having some difficulties.Fast forward to 2 days ago- See Max Payne on sale for like 3 bucks. Have you seen Max Payne the movie?? Yes? No? Either way, forget that movie- Play the game and you will NOT regret it.As Max Payne, you get put into a tragic situation that only your guns can solve. You work your way up, and just when you think you've reached the top- You realize you've only scratched the surface.Like I said before, there's the incredible story followed by great controls that make sense. Slow-Mo feature that works like bread and butter. The game IS challenging, if you're thinking slow mo makes stuff easy- you're wrong. Great length- Not long enough where you just want to get it done, not short enough where you feel like you've been gypped out of your cash.The graphics are dated- The game was released almost 14 years ago on the MAX-FX engine. It's what you would expect from a game released in 2001. The faces on these characters are also priceless- taking and giving damage yields grimacing results that has it's own charm.To sum up- The game's great- About 75% of the way through the game, I turned it off- Went to the steam store and bought Max Payne 2 and 3. I couldn't get enough. If you're a fan of the noir genre, this is for you. If you're a fan of action, this is for you, if you play fps and think that third person shooters wouldnt suit you, you're wrong- this game is for you. If you want to feel nostalgic and get a warm christmassy NYC vibe- THIS GAME IS FOR YOU.9.5/10 Loses half a point for the lack of diverse weaponry- I feel like I only got stuff that got the job done, but on the other hand- I am just a NYC copper. You get pretty much whatever a cop would get. (With the exception of an M79)Max Payne 2 is done downloading- I wont waste any more time writing this up!

The drawback on this step is that only a few people will have a mouse with its own control panel.NOTE: Thompaine suggests that "If you don't have a special mouse with it's own control program, you can go into the "Mouse" control panel (Win7 classic CP) and uncheck the box labeled "Enhance pointer precision" under the "Pointer Options" tab", which helped him after installing the patch (Thank you!)MOUSE LAG FIX #2: Go to your Max Payne folder and run maxpayne.exe in compatibility mode for Windows 95. Posted: August 15, 2014
												Max Payne is, in some ways, a very unique game, and in many other ways it is just another third person shooter.It really depends on how you look at it. Stylistically, Max Payne is very engaging simply because you don't really see a lot of video games in a 'Noir'-kind of setting; I really have never played a game that is anything like Max Payne! If Noir is your thing and you love yourself some of those 'bloody revenge' stories in which one guy shoots his way through Mafia goons, you will probably not be disappointed by Max Payne...... That is, if you are sure that you can handle old-school shooters. For someone like me, this game aged very well actually, since I do not mind these older shooting mechanics which simply involve you evading fire rather than covering from it. It's a very simplistic game in that sense; don't expect any sort of depth. That's not a fault of the game, but I have talked to players who could not get into the game because they thought these mechanics lacked the intricacies of newer shooting games, like cover-mechanics and upgradable weapons. Not to mention, death is inevitable in Max Payne, mostly because Max can die in just a few gunshots (it's 'realistic' that way) and because he does not regenerate health on his own, so expect to be overwhelmed by enemies more often than not. Some may call it frustrating, but I call it challenging!Players who grew up playing games that force you to constantly quick save, quick load and just abuse the terrain to get cheap shots at enemies will enjoy this game no matter what, I would say. There isn't any variation in gameplay, all you do is search for ammo and health, and then shoot bad guys - Nothing more, nothing less. Either way, Max Payne is a classic.

Posted: March 1, 2013
												Max Payne a man that lost everything and has nothing but the truth to find, a truth he wants, but sometimes the truth hurts, this is not the case. Max comes home from his job as a NYPD officer to find his loving wife and his baby daughter Rose dead, the people who killed them still in the house. He kills them and starts on a downward spiral trying to find what happened to his family.The game starts off straight forward enough, as far as a third person shooter goes it did two things 10 years ago when it came out, it set a standard for third person shooters, and it introduced bullet time. The only thing that sepreates you from the NPC's of Max's universe is the ability to heal and the ability to slow time, past that you are just as human, you will get frustrated. You will hate rounding a corner at full health and dying to a single bullet, but that is made up quickly with the ability to save anywhere, one tap of F5 and you save your state.The game does a good job of telling Max's story, you play him through his quest to find answers and this leads you to many different places, the levels all vary heavily, they rarely feel samy unless it a particulary long level, and that only happened once to me. The weapons list is short, you could drag it out if you included the dual weild function on some of the guns, but even then it's only the same gun in each hand, so they built the game to be simple but delivery very well.Most of Max Payne is focused on the narration that Max gives you and the story, it's different, enemies will talk to each other before you enter a room, some insight into thier lives or views, favorite movies and so on. The game is amazingly immersive and gives you alot to keep going, it's not afraid to break the fourth wall a couple of times to sell a few key points in the game, so it often adds to the immersion rather than taking it away.If i had to say one thing to sell Max Payne to someone is, if you like third person shooters, and want a good story, this is it. If you want a good game to play that passes the time and will give you some awesome noir quotes then this is the game for you.

 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Max Payne is the first game in the Max Payne trilogy developed by Remedy Entertainment, the same people behind the Alan Wake game and Quantum Break, produced by 3D Realms, makers of such classics as the Duke Nukem series and Commander Keen and published by none other than Rockstar Games, makers of such games as Bully, Manhunt, L.A. Noire and the Grand Theft Auto seriesYou play Max Payne, a police officer who experiences the death of his wife and new born daughter and is framed and under constant lookout by the New York Police Department (NYPD). Max Payne wants to seek revenge on the people who murdered his wife and daughter and bring them to justiceThis game is old, it came out in 2001 and it shows. Firstly, you will need a mod that fixes some compatibility issues and makes the game run on modern systems, so much so, you also need a mod that makes the game widescreen which makes it playable on widescreen monitors, however, you make experience graphical issues which thankfully I overlookedThe graphics, for what they were at the time have aged pretty well. The environments are well designed and the attention to detail is really there, however the character models such as Max Payne and other characters have aged horribly from other games released at the timeThe music and sound effects are good and the voice acting is good too. However, the game does suffer with volume level issues, sometimes the voice actors sound loud then at some points they sound low. Sometimes the cutscenes volume is good and at some points I can't hear a thing and have to riase the volume from my speakers to hear what they are saying, this is due to it being an old game so I don't blame the game per seiThe cutscenes are told through a form of a graphic novel and although I don't mind this, the graphic novel models such as the person playing Max Payne and other characters did not look authentic to the characters they are portraying and looked like they just went into a green screen room and took pictures just for funThe gameplay is a mixed bag. The famous bullet time is fun and will save you a lot of health as Max Payne dies easily, even on medium and easy difficulty. And the game is hard, you will die constantly, so much so, that I had to replay the game from medium difficulty to easy difficulty and still the game was hardYou will die constantly, and this is where my main complaint comes in. There is no auto save! If you get shot and die, you will reset to the latest save you or the game has done which is normally in the beginning of a chapter, so if you did not save manually (either by pressing F5 or by saving in the main menu), then expect to be teleported back to the latest save either you or the game did for you. This can be extremely annoying!However, Max Payne is a fantastic start to the trilogy and I can't wait to play Remedy's sequel; Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne and Rockstar's take in; Max Payne 3Max Payne runs pretty well on modern systems, just be sure to download a mod that fixes the compatibility issues and makes the game playable on widescreen monitors and you should be fine! Just be wary of the game's difficulty at some points... RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: April 8, 2016
												"NOTHING IS A CLICHE WHEN IT'S HAPPENING TO YOU."Max Payne is a third person shooter set in the gritty streets of New York City. Max, an undercover cop, witnesses the murder of his wife and infant child. This urges him to go on a warpath to seek vengeance and answers. Many consider this game to be a classic, and I think it holds up to the title.+The story is told in a graphic novel style. Artwork mostly looks like muddled photographs, but it fits the overall mood of the story. Each panel is fully voiced to great effect. Max Payne's grave tones steal the show, though the other performances are still up to par. The story itself is a classic revenge tale; it treads off the path with conspiracies and experimental drugs, but the main point of the story is Max gaining vengeance... In style.+Action. It's spot on. I usually don't care for third person shooters. The over the shoulder cameras can be pretty janky, movement is often delayed, and overall I feel like my accuracy hits the gutter. In Max Payne, however, I never had an issue. In fact, it uses the third person camera to its advantage. With bullet time dodges, you can maneuver the character in ways that actually help you in combat. While it looks cool, it all serves a purpose. With quick wits and the right doges, you can clear rooms in a way that is immensely satisfying. Nothing is better than sweeping a group of baddies in a single slow-motion dive.~Graphically, the game hasn't aged very well. Facial models are clearly just photgraphs and a lot of the environments don't really feature anything too impressive to look at. Animations, as well, can be a bit strange looking. Using melee weapons feels just wrong, and Max's default stance is questionable. That said, I'm sure it was good for the time.-Environments. There aren't many. Most of the game takes place in narrow corridors, factories, and harbors. While the level design seemed to flow well enough, I wasn't too impressed with variety. Discounting the dream worlds and the satanic nightclub, Max Payne doesn't have much to offer in interesting locales.VERDICTMax Payne is a game everyone should try. It's fun, it's frantic, and it's worth experiencing. Fans of shooters should explore the title, as it offers much more--in terms of gameplay--than many current games. It's not a long game, clocking in at maybe seven hours, but it's worth the low price that age warrants.Play it.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												Max Payne is, in some ways, a very unique game, and in many other ways it is just another third person shooter.It really depends on how you look at it. Stylistically, Max Payne is very engaging simply because you don't really see a lot of video games in a 'Noir'-kind of setting; I really have never played a game that is anything like Max Payne! If Noir is your thing and you love yourself some of those 'bloody revenge' stories in which one guy shoots his way through Mafia goons, you will probably not be disappointed by Max Payne...... That is, if you are sure that you can handle old-school shooters. For someone like me, this game aged very well actually, since I do not mind these older shooting mechanics which simply involve you evading fire rather than covering from it. It's a very simplistic game in that sense; don't expect any sort of depth. That's not a fault of the game, but I have talked to players who could not get into the game because they thought these mechanics lacked the intricacies of newer shooting games, like cover-mechanics and upgradable weapons. Not to mention, death is inevitable in Max Payne, mostly because Max can die in just a few gunshots (it's 'realistic' that way) and because he does not regenerate health on his own, so expect to be overwhelmed by enemies more often than not. Some may call it frustrating, but I call it challenging!Players who grew up playing games that force you to constantly quick save, quick load and just abuse the terrain to get cheap shots at enemies will enjoy this game no matter what, I would say. There isn't any variation in gameplay, all you do is search for ammo and health, and then shoot bad guys - Nothing more, nothing less. Either way, Max Payne is a classic.

												If my display picture is still displayed as "3d Realms", and my username is still the same, then some people may think my review is biased, so I'll give it to you straight.I'm guilty of not being able to play Max Payne until 2013. I also only became part of 3d Realms in 2015.That being said, I experienced the series firsthand early in the year, and it blew me away. I also have no "nostalgic" value for it, so my review is based on how I played it and experienced it as a gamer in modern times.This game is amazing, but takes some getting used to. Old-school health system, and extremely fast paced action make this an interesting title, where even low difficulty may take some modern gamers by surprise. The game is set in an awesome dark 1990s Noir setting with lots of interesting story to hear, and the awesome writing of the legendary Sam Lake (writer for Alan Wake by Remedy), coupled with the occasional bits of humour and witty one-liners.Lots of fast-paced gun action with bullet time makes for a gritty New York cop story, and definitely something worth experiencing. The story extends over the next two games (Max Payne 2 and Max Payne 3).If you want some oldschool (read: CHALLENGING) action for a change, this game is the one for you. Don't expect regenerating health and the ability to take 10000 bullets without dying whilst jelly jam runs down the screen. You will get shot, and you will probably die quite a few times on your first playthrough, but the experience is made fun by the awesome setting, bullettime action and the witty (and occasionally humourous) dialogue.I wouldn't recommend this if you want a more modern cover-based shooter with good graphics.

Posted: January 14, 2016
												I love Max Payne. I own the game on multiple platforms and have just completed it on Steam.Max Payne is a third-person shooter action thriller that centers on the NYPD Detective Max Payne, who attempts to avenge the murder of his family. It features a gritty neo-noirstyle and uses graphic novel panels (with voice-overs) in place of animated cutscenes to narrate the game, as it draws inspiration from hard-boiled detective novels by authors like Mickey Spillane. The gameplay is heavily influenced by the Hong Kong action cinema genre, particularly the work of director John Woo, and it was one of the first games to feature the bullet time effect popularized by The Matrix.While the graphics are now dated the game is still enjoyable to play and the story and voice acting is fantasic.I would highly recommend this game. Posted: January 20, 2016
												"Smoke rose from the sewers below like all the fires of hell were beneath us." Awesome quotes like that make Max Payne sweet as candy. The game concerns the eponymous hero and tells a peaceful story about his blissful retirement from the NYPD and how he lives happily ever after with his wife and kids. Or not. The game concerns his "Taken style" journey for vengeance after his family are brutally slain by junkies high on a new drug. Valkyrie. The game is (in my mind) split into two seperate parts, the gameplay and the story. The gameplay concerns Max running through new york killing everyone he sees, you use different guns (a lot of them) and have the option of going into bullet time (slowing down time like a family reunion) but fundamentally the gameplay is derivative and repetitive. There's a link with the general pessimisitic film noir tone of the game and how depressed and angry Max is but that doesn't neccessarily excuse gameplay which is so lacking in variety.The story of the game involves tracking down who was responsible for the crime and is told partly through graphic novel style scripts with gritty voiceover, partly through cutscenes using the in-game engine but probably most interestingly through the environment of the game in the form of graffiti, doodads and various TV shows which are variously sinister and funny and educational.The main problem of the game (for me) is (as previously mentioned) the actual gameplay of the game becomes a chore one has to work through to access the storyline (which is interesting and thought provoking). I guess it's kind of like playing an RPG where all the battles seem like a means to the end of enjoying the narrative and you actually wish the game would just be super easy so you could get what you actually want out of it with the minimum of fuss.Overall the game is very interesting and different but has that rather large flaw. Still worth a look.

Posted: July 16, 2015
												This is one of those special-place-in-my-heart games that elicits some kind of catharsis every time it's played.  The setting, gameplay, soundtrack, dialogue, artwork - it all comes together in this strange culmination of dark justice.   Max Payne loses in the end, whether he wins or not.  He's doomed from the start, and a lot of games don't torture their heroes this much.  So from the beginning you're in this nothing-to-lose mentality alongside our protagonist.  The mechanics even support this idea, as you can restart from the last point of death if you mash the quicksave button like an underlying arc from a Lost episode.  Events replay like you went back in time a few seconds prior to your blundered encounter and decided to duck left instead of right.  The gaming community criticized this feature when it released all those years ago, and people are still kind of iffy on it because of its linear drive.  This game really is a comic come to life.  The setting is as much a character as Max is, rife with loneliness and torment - slowly picked apart by what can only be described as a 100-year winter.  New York City is the target of the Norse Gods' "♥♥♥♥-this-place-in-particular" ice beam of misery, effectively isolating Max and a thousand goons to do glorious battle in Thunderdome 2.0.  The reason this game is and will always be timeless is because you don't need to inject yourself into 2001 to appreciate this title for all that it is.  It's a story that can be told over and over.

												I rarely review games and only do so when I really REALLY enjoy the title.I've known about Max Payne for years, I've watched my brother play it over 8 years ago and actually picked it up before. I didn't play much of it because I remember having some difficulties.Fast forward to 2 days ago- See Max Payne on sale for like 3 bucks. That's a deal for any game, I'll give it a shot.I got news for you, this game is incredible. It's one long action movie that is intricate and leaves you like a junkie looking for more Valkyr. Have you seen Max Payne the movie?? Yes? No? Either way, forget that movie- Play the game and you will NOT regret it.As Max Payne, you get put into a tragic situation that only your guns can solve. You work your way up, and just when you think you've reached the top- You realize you've only scratched the surface.Like I said before, there's the incredible story followed by great controls that make sense. Slow-Mo feature that works like bread and butter. The game IS challenging, if you're thinking slow mo makes stuff easy- you're wrong. Great length- Not long enough where you just want to get it done, not short enough where you feel like you've been gypped out of your cash.The graphics are dated- The game was released almost 14 years ago on the MAX-FX engine. It's what you would expect from a game released in 2001. The faces on these characters are also priceless- taking and giving damage yields grimacing results that has it's own charm.To sum up- The game's great- About 75% of the way through the game, I turned it off- Went to the steam store and bought Max Payne 2 and 3. I couldn't get enough. If you're a fan of the noir genre, this is for you. If you're a fan of action, this is for you, if you play fps and think that third person shooters wouldnt suit you, you're wrong- this game is for you. If you want to feel nostalgic and get a warm christmassy NYC vibe- THIS GAME IS FOR YOU.9.5/10 Loses half a point for the lack of diverse weaponry- I feel like I only got stuff that got the job done, but on the other hand- I am just a NYC copper. 												My expierence with Max Payne before playing this game was a short stint on Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne when I was younger. Although I liked it alot, I never thought to revisit it or explore the series. With the games now being so cheap here on Steam I decided to give them a full playthrough each.To sum up how I feel about this game, I'd find it hard to not recommend it. Yes the visuals have dated, but not to the extent that it looks ugly. The game offers all modern resolutions and run (at least for me) as smooth as butter.Infact the only real issue I had with the game in terms of running it was a sound bug with was easily fixed with a small player created patch, it's likely you'll have to do the same.Gameplay wise, it's a run of the mill third person shooter. The real sell point of this game aside from it's story is the bullet time ability. One click of a button and you'll enter bullet time, being able to perform rolls, jumps and dodges. It's not just a gimmick either, the game's high difficulty means you'll have to make use of it, but that's okay because it feels so smooth and natural to pull off bullet time kills.The story and character of Max Payne is the other real catch here. Max is troubled, his deep poetic self expression through the game is well placed and well wrote. You'll find him describing just about everything you come across of note with a clever, noir style of depressive reckoning. The story is one of vengence, it's not out of place and keeps the action following nicely.I would highly recommend giving this game ago. It's dated sure, but not to the point where you can't enjoy it.

Posted: January 10, 2016
												After playing through this entire game, i concluded that this game, while old, is still an okay game. The story for Max Payne is hands down ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. It tells the story of Max Payne, an ex-cop that lost his wife and child in a home invasion. This leaves Max Payne depressed and addicted to Pain Killers and Alcohol. This leads Max Payne on a road to revenge as he tracks down the werabouts of the man who killed his loved ones. That sounds good on its own, reading the story is like a book, or a graphic novel. The Gameplay is pretty decent. You run-n-gun your way through repetitive hordes of mafia gangs and eventually, hired private army gunmen. The game is very repetitive. The main draw this game offers is a game mechanic called Bullet Time. Basically, you slow down time to aim better and avoid getting shot, this mechanic is unreliable at times and got me killed alot, though this mechanic is alot better in Max Payne 3 (great game btw). This game actually forces you to think carefully instead of running into a room on mafia/army guards because 1 bullet drains alot of health. Painkillers are used as health and slowly regain your health back. They are very scarce and Iwas always begging for a Painkiller so i didn't die. Thankfully, you can save your game at any point, excluding cutscenes of course. As i said before, i died alot due to the scare of Painkillers, lots of damage obsorbance and the Bullet Time mechanic ♥♥♥♥ing me over. I later found out that this game uses Escalated Diffuculty, meaning that if your doing really well and finding the game too easy, the game bumps up the difficulty without warning, making hard parts already harder. Overall this game is Decent, 6/10 at best but i'm really reccomending this game for its story because i absolutly loved it. 6/10, May Play Again.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												Ah yes, Max Payne. One of the few crowning jewels coming out of a finnish game company and probably one of the most well known game franchises and one of the underrated as well, if I may say so myself. Celebrating 15 years since the release of this game I will share a bit of my thoughts about this game.Despite being released all the way back in 2001, I think this game is still enjoyable to play til this day, sure the graphics isn't top notch from today's standards, but that's something to be expected from such an already old game. But if we do put the graphics away, it still a fairly enjoyable game. I think the story is still holding up pretty well, it keeps you wanting to play more and more til the very end. A few interesting mechanics in this game, like the mixing of visual novel into this game for an example, something you rarely get to see in a video game, not to often at least.And then there's the always enjoyable slow motion sequences, where you can throw yourself in whatever direction and slow the time down to make it easier to shoot the enemies. Then we of course got the brilliant punny way to give your health back...Paynekillers, ha, get it? Cause his name is..and he takes them to...yeah let's just move on. Instead of taking up health packs or any kind of orbs to heal himself, he eats painkillers, now if you're not too careful you will be using a lot of these, so be cautious of how many you swallow down.If you haven't had the chance to play this game yet, or if you have never heard of this game before, I personally would definitely recommend you giving it a try.

												This game is really old, but the narrative is a classic. Yeah, this game came out in 2001, but at the time, games like these were considered technical achievements and true masterpieces, including Grand Theft Auto III, another Rockstar game. I really like the gritty atmosphere and the intriging story, although at times, the story can get a bit too far fetched and left me a bit detached on what I was doing. The bullet time effect is the best part of the game as I used it often to surprise enemies and enter rooms guns ablazing. The soundtrack in this game is really composed well and fits fine in the mentioned gritty atmosphere, and even during the graphic novel-like cutscenes.Now the A.I. in this game can go from clunky to just plain bad at times; running in circles, shooting at the walls, and not responding from getting shot multiple times. I shot an enemy with a shotgun from the back and it took him four seconds to turn around and shoot me.Lastly, I found it cumbersome in fixing the age-old issue of missing audio and sounds. Even though there is an external fix for it, I really wished that Rockstar applied the fix as an official update a LONG time ago or letting Steam giving us an update. I don't want to download files here and put the files there just to have the game work.Would I recommend this game to anyone? Definitely yas! Anyone who is a fan of suspense and crime drama or wanting to try a new game series will be delighted to play this game and continue on with its sequels. Max Payne is my entrance to the exploits and universe of Max Payne and after I complete this game, Max Payne 2 is next and Max Payne 3 on the PS3 (will get a PC version of it sometime down the line when I upgrade my computer). Rating: 7.5/10

Posted: December 3, 2016
 One of my all time favorites, a classic that has truly stood the test of time.	I first heard of the praise to this game when I was glancing on some regular videos on the internet, and boy was it worshipped to death. I fed into the bait and bought it and boy was it anything but a waste of money. This continues to be in my personal "Hall of Fame" in gaming history.Story:Following the man known as...you guessed it, Max Payne who is returning home on a bright and sunny evening after work to be with his wife and baby in New York. When he gets home he finds his house in shambles, cuboards were broken open, bookcases on the floor in ruins, symbols with a strange syringe of mysterious meanings and blood sprewn everywhere. When he goes upstairs he hears screams and shouts coming from a couple rooms over. Then a man bursts out of a nearby door and Max is forced to shoot him for his own safety. He enters the room the man appeared from and he finds his dead baby on the floor. Fearing the worst already, he hears more shouts and screams from the next room over, he opens the door to find more men and is again forced to put them down...but...his wife is covered with blood on the bed, obviously dead. I won't be telling anymore but if you think these are spoilers then you will be mistaken as they are at the very start of the game, so don't worry. It is actually not that bad of a story in my opinion and is quite good at giving you a sense of "unfairness" in his life.Soundtrack:This section is important because be warned, this game is INCREDIBLY PRONE TO BUGGED SOUND AND MUSIC IF YOU ARE PLAYING ON A MODERN SYSTEM. There are however various fixes and guides in the community to fix these very huge issues so it isn't as bad but I still got massive audio problems even with a patch, so be aware of that. But if by some miracle you happen to fix the major issues with the sound and music then I promise you won't be disappointed, this game contains beautiful and memorable pieces, especially at the end in my honest opinion.Voice Acting:The voice acting is decent enough and definitely has its moments of good...but also its bad. At parts it is REALLY good, especially the voice for Max Payne himself. But as for other characters it's OK. But unfortunately some voice acting can be blocked out by the same audio issues I stated earlier.Gameplay:The very first thing to state about the (awesome) gameplay, is the trademark "Bullet Time." This unique and profound ability is very useful in combat that is obviously used to see where bullets will hit and try to sneak around them. Besides being useful this isn't really something that you see in other games these days, and is the number one noticable thing about the game that continues to be developed into the newer games. I might mention this game is EXTREMELY hard, even on the very first difficulty, I can assure you that at one point or another you WILL get frustrated or angry (like I did), I would not reccomend this for those who have problematic anger issues or other conditions as this game can cause unforseen consenquences. Enemies are going to get more resistant to damage the later you get in the game, being moderately resistant to even the strongest weapons. Since this game is incredibly challenging, there would have to be some sort of uncumbersome saving system, and it is the glorious Quick Saving mechanic, this is going to be a lifesaver and will pretty much be mandatory for later difficulties after every enemy encounter. Speaking of difficulty, a total of four difficulties are present in the game. Fugitive, Hard-Boiled, Dead on Arrival, and finally New York Minute. 1. Fugitive:Unlocked automatically. Fugitive is the first difficulty you have when you have the option of starting a new game, if you beat it then you unlock Hard-Boiled and New York Minute. Fugitive is a challenging difficulty even for newcomers like myself as stated earlier. Nothing really to state here besides being the very first difficulty before the other ones.2. Hard-Boiled:Unlocked after beating Fugitive. I personally haven't played this difficulty yet since I wanted to instantly review this game first chance I got. Although it's obvious that this difficulty is harder than that of the likes of Fugitive, it is a second challenge if you are up to it after beating the game one time.3. Dead on Arrival:Unlocked after beating Hard-Boiled difficulty. The hardest setting out of every difficulty. I haven't played this since I didn't beat Hard-Boiled but I can't imagine what kind of rage one would get out of playing this. Without a doubt a difficulty challenge for any veteran of...well, anything.4. New York Minute:Unlocked after beating Fugitive difficulty. The same level of difficulty as Fugitive if I'm correct...but with a major twist. NYM now adds a time-limit to every single segment/level within the game, making every second a race against the clock. I have never completed this and I don't know anyone who has but if you're up to the challenge then go for it! :DI could say a lot more about this game, and even though I absolutely hated its guts at times due to spiked up difficulty, it was still a really fun joyride.8.4/10. An awesome game.
